item.title: The Fed slashed its 2025 growth forecast while raising its inflation forecast
item.description: PANews reported on March 20 that according to Tonghuashun Finance, the Federal Reserve FOMC economic forecast shows that the median GDP growth forecast for the end of 2025 to 2027 is 1.7%, 1.8%, and 1.8%, respectively, and the forecasts in December are 2.1%, 2.0%, and 1.9%, respectively. The median forecasts for the federal funds rate from 2025 to 2027 are 3.9%, 3.4%, and 3.1%, respectively, and the forecasts in December are 3.9%, 3.4%, and 3.1%, respectively. The median forecasts for the unemployment rate from 2025 to 2027 are 4.4%, 4.3%, and 4.3%, respectively, and the forecasts in December are 4.3%, 4.3%, and 4.3%, respectively. The median forecasts for core PCE inflation from 2025 to 2027 are 2.8%, 2.2%, and 2.0%, respectively, and the forecasts in December are 2.5%, 2.2%, and 2.0%, respectively.
item.author: PANews

item.title: The Federal Reserve kept its policy rate unchanged and began to slow down the pace of balance sheet reduction on April 1
item.description: PANews, March 20 news, according to Wall Street Journal, the Federal Reserve held steady - maintaining the federal funds rate target range at 4.25%-4.50%, in line with market expectations. Starting April 1, the pace of balance sheet reduction will be slowed, with the monthly cap on the reduction of US Treasuries lowered to $50 billion, while the monthly reduction of mortgage-backed securities (MBS) will remain unchanged at $35 billion. The statement said: the uncertainty facing the economy has increased, the 2025 growth forecast has been lowered, and the inflation forecast has been raised. The language about the roughly balanced risks to the Federal Reserve's (maintaining price stability + achieving full employment) goals has been omitted. Federal Reserve Governor Waller supported the FOMC's interest rate decision this time, but dissented on the balance sheet decision.

item.title: The operator of the Russian sanctioned crypto trading platform Garantex is suspected of transferring customer funds to a new platform
item.description: On March 20, according to The Block, a report by the analysis firm Global Ledger showed that the operator of the sanctioned Russian cryptocurrency exchange Garantex is suspected of launching a new trading platform called Grinex and transferring client funds to that platform. Grinex is still operating in Russia and has many similarities to Garantex, which was sanctioned by international agencies earlier this month. On-chain data shows that Grinex has already processed transactions worth nearly $30 million. Global Ledger stated: "These investigation results indicate that Grinex is not an independent entity, but the official successor to Garantex, and although the trading platform has officially closed, it continues to conduct financial operations."

item.title: Analyst: The Fed's revision of economic expectations will not have a significant impact on financial markets
item.description: Odaily Odaily News: Josh Jamner, senior investment analyst at Clearbridge, an investment company, believes that the Fed's economic expectations suggest that policymakers now expect economic conditions to be less favorable this year, with a moderate slowdown in the economy and rising inflation and unemployment. These changes are consistent with the expectations of banks and macroeconomic research institutions circulating on Wall Street in recent weeks, so in our view, these changes will not have a significant impact on financial markets. Ultimately, the Fed's policy will give way to fiscal policy, and pricing in the federal funds futures market suggests that the next rate cut will not occur until July, and this dynamic is unlikely to change in the short term.

item.title: Economists: Be cautious when betting on Fed rate cuts
item.description: Odaily News reports that Casey Bostic, an observer of the Federal Reserve and chief economist at the UK mortgage company Nationwide, has warned people to be cautious about betting on the Federal Reserve's rate cuts. She believes that investors are too eager to digest the impact of rate cuts, and as concerns about a sharp economic slowdown intensify, they generally expect the Federal Reserve's "Fed put" to cushion economic activity. Even if it is assumed that economic activity does not decline sharply, persistent high inflation and inflationary pressures from tariffs may cause the Federal Reserve to remain on hold for longer than the market expects. (Gold Ten)

item.title: Powell mentions "tariffs" and admits that Trump's policies affect the economy
item.description:
According to ChainCatcher's message, Federal Reserve Chairman Powell first mentioned the "tariff" issue at the press conference. When asked about the revision of inflation forecasts and the extent to which tariffs have affected inflation forecasts, he said it was difficult to analyze how much inflation was driven by tariff policies, but they would strive to figure it out: "It's clear that a large part of it comes from tariffs."

In addition, Powell pointed out that the policies of the new Trump administration would affect the economy, but he would cautiously avoid making too explicit judgments about this impact. Analysts pointed out that this might be his attempt, and he said he would closely monitor the monthly data to avoid the outside world's expectations about how all this would develop.

item.title: Powell: The economy is strong, slowing the balance sheet reduction is a "technical" decision
item.description:
According to ChainCatcher news, Federal Reserve Chairman Powell stated in a press conference that the U.S. economy is strong, and the decision to slow the pace of quantitative tightening (QT) is a "technical" one.

Powell said he is currently evaluating economic data, and while recent data shows consumer spending has slowed and household uncertainty has increased, he added that this is occurring on the basis of rapid growth in recent years. Powell also stated that the labor market conditions remain solid.
